awd_titl_txt: The Arctic ocean control of the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation on multi-decadal and longer timescales
awd_abstract_narration:
A major goal of this study is to understand the impacts of Arctic climate change and their effects on the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC). This is of significant practical value because the AMOC can affect the climate of different regions of the globe, ranging from North America, Europe and Greenland to the Sahel and the Indian Ocean. Drs. Fedorov and Liu will conduct outreach activities through the Peabody Museum of Natural History. This includes giving public lectures and symposia, leading Teacher development workshops, and communicating the importance of the results to mass media.

This is a modeling proposal to study the effect of declining Arctic sea ice on the strength and other characteristics of the AMOC - a major element of ocean dynamics and climate. Sea ice decline exposes the Arctic ocean to anomalous solar radiation and freshwater fluxes, generating positive buoyancy anomalies in the upper ocean. The hypothesis being tested is   that, when spreading to the North Atlantic these buoyancy anomalies effectively weaken ocean deep convection, leading to a slow-down of the AMOC on multi-decadal timescales. This hypothesis will be tested with a variety of methods ranging from adjoint ocean modeling to experiments with climate models.

por.por_cntn:
A dramatic decline of Arctic sea ice has occurred over the past three decades when the annual-mean sea ice extent decreased by over 20%. At the same time, there is tentative evidence of the slowdown of the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC) - a major element of ocean dynamics and climate. Climate models predict an even greater future contraction of Arctic sea ice, causing the disappearance of permanent sea ice by the end of the 21st century, and a further AMOC slowdown. Accordingly, the overarching goal of this project is to understand the effect of declining Arctic sea ice on AMOC and, more generally, to examine Arctic sea ice/AMOC interactions. In parallel, we aimed to investigate the dynamics and stability of the AMOC in a warming climate, and the impacts of other ocean basins on the AMOC, Arctic sea ice and the North Atlantic and Arctic climates. Some of the key findings of this work are summarized below:

AMOC slowdown induced by Arctic sea ice decline: We explored the mechanisms by which the Arctic sea ice decline affected the AMOC in a suite of numerical experiments perturbing Arctic sea ice radiative budget. The imposed perturbations act to increase the amount of heat available to melt ice, leading to a rapid Arctic sea ice retreat within 5 years after the perturbations are activated. In response, the AMOC gradually weakens over the next  century. The AMOC changes are explained by the accumulation in the Arctic and subsequent downstream propagation to the North Atlantic of buoyancy anomalies controlled by temperature and salinity. We further find that AMOC responses to Arctic sea ice decline across different climate models can differ qualitatively, which may be related to AMOC stability. For example, in a model with a less stable AMOC, sea ice decline comparable to the observed results in a 30-40% slowdown of the AMOC, but in models with a more stable AMOC, the AMOC weakens by about 10%-15% but eventually recovers.

Two-way interactions between Arctic sea ice and the AMOC: We analyzed a broad suite of control, historical and future climate model simulations to demonstrate that two-way interactions link variations in Arctic sea ice and the AMOC. These interactions are characterized by two distinct regimes. In the first regime, AMOC variations control Arctic sea ice: AMOC weakening drives sea ice expansion within several years, resulting from reduced ocean poleward heat transport. In the second regime, Arctic sea ice changes control the AMOC strength with a delay: sea ice contraction leads to an AMOC slow-down after several decades. The latter effect is caused by positive buoyancy anomalies spreading from the Arctic to the North Atlantic and suppressing deep convection.

Climate impacts of the AMOC slowdown in a warming climate: We developed a novel method to study the impacts of a weakening AMOC on the future climate. This method stabilizes the AMOC intensity in anthropogenic climate warming numerical experiments by gradually removing freshwater from the subpolar North Atlantic. Our results show that the weakened AMOC can explain ocean cooling south of Greenland that resembles the so-called North Atlantic Warming Hole and a reduced Arctic sea ice loss in all seasons with a delay of about 6 years in the emergence of an ice-free Arctic in boreal summer.

The effect of enhanced Indian ocean warming on the AMOC and North Atlantic/Arctic climates: We investigated how a salient feature of global warming, the enhanced warming of the tropical Indian Ocean (TIO), could affect the AMOC and the North Atlantic and Arctic climates. A surprising result is that TIO warming has a stabilizing effect on the AMOC, which may be counteracting the AMOC slow-down due to the increased stratification in the North Atlantic caused by warming and Arctic sea ice decline. This robust effect is explained by atmospheric teleconnections connecting TIO to North Atlantic high latitudes (imposing a positive NAO-like pattern) and low latitudes (reducing precipitation and increasing salinity).

At different stages, the project supported three postdoctoral researchers ? Drs. Wei Liu, Hui Li and recently Joshua Studholme. Wei Liu is now Assistant Professor at University of California Riverside and Hui Li is Project Scientist at NCAR. The project also involved two undergraduate students, who defended their B.S. thesis under PI?s supervision - Holden Leslie-Bole, currently a PhD student at Scripps, and Clara Ma, a PhD student at Cambridge.

PI Fedorov co-authored 12 publications, including several papers in Nature Climate Change, Nature communications and Science Advances, and a comprehensive review article in JGR focusing on the stability of the AMOC. Several more papers are at work. The results of the project have been presented at the AGU, EGU, Ocean Sciences and other conferences and workshops. Lastly, this project enhanced the capacity for global climate modeling and analysis by graduate and undergraduate students at Yale.
